content:
Welcome, you are participating in a negotiation game. You are playing as the agent named Alice. The other agent with whom you are playing is named Bob. In this game, two agents bargain over how to divide items over multiple rounds. The number of rounds is incredibly high. Each agent only knows their own item values. Each item has different values for each agent. Each agent submits their own proposal for how to divide the items.


Your messages must be sent in this exact format:
<message>
your-message-here
</message>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. They should be concise - less than 400 characters. Finalization is not allowed in messages.


Your finalizations must be sent in this exact format:
<finalize>
{  "Alice": {    "coins": x  },  "Bob": {    "coins": y  }}
</finalize>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. Your proposal should be consistent with itself - the sum of items that you propose for yourself and the items that you propose for the other agent should equal the total available items.


Each round is played as follows:
1) One agent is designated as the starting agent
2) The starting agent sends a message
3) The second agent sends a message
4) The starting agent sends a finalization
5) The second agent sends a finalization

Each agent can only send 1 message per round.
The starting agent alternates each round.

Each agent only knows the values of items from their own perspective. You cannot see the other agent's item values unless they explicitly share this information in their messages. And vice versa. You are strongly encouraged to use your messages to discuss item values with the other agent.

The items obtained by each agent at the end of a round are proportional to the number of items they proposed for themselves in their finalization. First example: If both players propose to take all the items, they both get half. Second example: If one agent proposes to take all the items and the other agent proposes to take none, the first agent gets all the items and the second agent gets nothing.

Your round points are calculated by multiplying the number of each item you get by how much you value that item. For example, if you get 7 coins and you value each coin at 5 points, you'll earn 35 points for the round.


Your goal is to maximize the sum of the points you will accumulate over the course of the game, not the points of a single round.


Before the game starts, you must strategize. The other player will adapt its strategy with respect to yours. Make sure you act in a way that incentivizes the other player to act in a way that maximizes the sum of the points you will accumulate over the course of the game, not the points of a single round. In order to strategize, you must use the format:
<strategize>
Your thoughts and strategy here..
</strategize>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. You should think inside the tags. You can use 500 characters inside the tags.
(You must now send a strategize in the correct format.)


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<strategize>
My strategy is to initially propose fair and balanced distributions to build trust with Bob. I will focus on understanding his item values through messages and aim to identify items he values less, so I can claim a larger share of them. I’ll adjust my proposals in subsequent rounds to maximize points, ensuring Bob feels he's getting fair terms to avoid aggressive counter-proposals. Over time, I will adapt my strategy based on Bob's responses to optimize long-term gains.
</strategize>

The other agent sent the following message: <strategize>
My strategy is to prioritize cooperation and transparency to build trust with Alice. I will openly share my item values and encourage Alice to do the same. This will help us identify mutually beneficial distributions. I'll propose equitable splits but will be flexible in adjusting for items that Alice values more, especially if I value them less. I'll focus on consistency in my proposals to encourage Alice to maintain a collaborative approach, maximizing my points over many rounds.
</strategize>.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Bob were {'coins': 16}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 9}.
The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Alice! For this round, I'm valuing each coin at 12 points on my end. I see there are 10 coins available. Could you share how much you value the coins? This way, we can aim to find a fair distribution that maximizes points for both of us. Looking forward to your thoughts!
</message>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Bob! Thanks for sharing your values. I value each coin at 9 points. With 10 coins available, I suggest we aim for a fair distribution like 5 coins each, allowing us both to benefit proportionally. Since you value the coins slightly more, would you propose an adjustment that still feels fair to both? I'm open to hearing your thoughts to reach a mutually beneficial agreement.
</message>

The other agent has finalized.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Bob were {'coins': 12}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 12}.
You are the starting agent.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Bob! This round, I value each coin at 12 points. Given there are 10 coins available, how do you value them this round? Knowing this, we can work towards a distribution that maximizes value for both of us. I'd propose starting with an even split, but I'm open to adjustments if it benefits us both. Looking forward to your response!
</message>

The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Alice! This round, I value each coin at 8 points. Since you value them more highly, I'd be open to an uneven split that favors you a bit more. Perhaps something like you taking 6 coins while I take 4? Let me know if this sounds fair or if you have another suggestion that maximizes points for us both!
</message>.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Bob were {'coins': 8}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 5}.
The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Alice! This round, I value each coin at 13 points. Could you share how you value the coins this round? Considering the values, it might be reasonable for me to propose taking a larger share if you value them less. However, I'm keen to hear your perspective, and I'm open to finding a fair balance that optimizes the benefits for both of us.
</message>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Bob! This round, I value each coin at 5 points. Given your higher valuation at 13 points, it makes sense for you to take a larger share. I'm open to you taking 7 coins while I take 3, allowing you to maximize your points. Let me know if this distribution works for you or if you have any adjustments in mind. Looking forward to your thoughts!
</message>

The other agent has finalized.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)
